Award.AwardTitle: Tennessee Valley Tri-State LSAMP Pre-Alliance Planning

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority (URM)populations(African-Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians or Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders) to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM.<br/><br/>The LSAMP Pre-Alliance Planning effort for a potential Tennessee Valley Tri-State STEM Pathways and Implementation-Only (SPIO) alliance in 2022 involving the University of North Alabama, Mississippi University for Women, the University of Mississippi-Martin, East Mississippi Community College and Northwest-Shoals Community College with other non-academic organizations will allow an extensive network a platform from which to evaluate and develop inter-institutional resources, policies and pathways to improve graduation rates for URMs in STEM in this predominantly rural U.S. region. This planning period will a) yield new information about the effectiveness of a diverse array of partners to formalize an Alliance; b) provide a comprehensive assessment of the current suite of services, resources, and opportunities offered to URM STEM undergraduates and determine where the gaps exist; and c) design and promote new pathways with evidence-based activities that will improve the numbers of URM undergraduates in STEM fields. Regionally, this work will provide knowledge to advance a specially targeted cohort of students by implementing activities that will be sustainable for the proposed network of partners, including employers. With a strong blend of academic and administrative leadership experiences in STEM fields, this team offers an understanding of the barriers and challenges faced by students and families in surrounding rural areas of the targeted tri-state region. Through this planning effort, new pathways will be enabled that, otherwise, would not converge without such a concerted effort.<br/><br/>The results from this project will be used to develop a full proposal in 2022 to establish a successful model through the NSF LSAMP STEM Pathways Implementation-Only (SPIO) funding opportunity for recruitment, retention, graduation, and post-graduate success of primarily rural students from historically underrepresented backgrounds in STEM disciplines. By assessing current resources and approaches, we will establish and formalize pathways from rural northern Alabama, rural Mississippi and rural Tennessee in preparation for a full Alliance that will be both responsive and competitive for workforce needs across this tri-state region. This planning grant will enable strategic partnerships that will ultimately strengthen the tri-state's collective economy and infuse the national job market with highly trained STEM professionals who hail from rural settings and will be prepared to make economic and social contributions in STEM fields.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority (URMs) populations to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM. STEM occupation growth for the Tennessee Valley is forecasted at 34% by 2026 according to the Alabama Department of Labor. Most of these jobs are concentrated in industrial pockets surrounded by rural communities. The institutions of higher education in the Tennessee Valley, while primarily located within these industrial pockets, largely draw their student composition from rural communities. However, the number of STEM baccalaureate graduates produced by institutions of higher education is insufficient to meet the forecasted 2026 STEM occupational demand. STEM benchmark testing data show promise with high school students’ interest in at least one of the STEM disciplines; however, students fail to meet STEM testing benchmarks for preparation and potential retention success. The preparation for underrepresented minorities, low-income, and/or first-generation college students provide a more concerning outlook. As the purpose of the LSAMP program, the pipeline of underrepresented minorities into STEM disciplines and on to STEM employment needs re-engineering and realignment with national priorities.   

The University of North Alabama (UNA) has been awarded as the lead institution for the Tennessee Valley Tri-State LSAMP program for the 2023-2028 project period. The Tennessee Valley LSAMP (TV-LSAMP) recognizes their unique position to undertake a series of activities to fill a critical need for creating a pipeline of URM STEM baccalaureate graduates across this rural Southeastern region. In addition, the TV-LSAMP Alliance will work together to create, enhance and expand programs designed to broaden participation and increase the quality and quantity of students from underrepresented populations who receive degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. The University of North Alabama is honored to be working with the University of Tennessee Martin (UTM), Mississippi University for Women (MUW) and Northwest Shoals Community College (NWSCC). 

The Tennessee Valley LSAMP Pre-Alliance process efforts from 2021-2023 provided UNA, UTM, MUW, and NWSCC a platform to evaluate and develop inter-institutional resources and policies, thus a “pathway” to reduce the deficit of URMs in STEM graduates in this predominantly rural U.S. region. The Tennessee Valley LSAMP has developed a comprehensive assessment of the current suite of services, resources, and opportunities offered to URM STEM undergraduates to determine where the gaps exist. Evidenced-based activities were designed for implementation to improve the numbers of URM undergraduates in STEM fields and advance a large cohort of students that will be sustainable for the proposed network of partners, including employers. With a strong blend of academic and administrative leadership experiences in STEM fields, this team offers an understanding of the barriers and challenges faced by students and families in surrounding rural areas of the targeted tri-state region. These strategic partnerships will ultimately strengthen the tri-state’s collective economy and infuse the national job market with highly trained STEM professionals who hail from rural settings and are prepared to make economic and social contributions in the growing array of STEM fields.

Over the next five years, some themes guiding the Tennessee Valley LSAMP’s efforts to increase URM STEM student enrollment, retention, and graduation include: 1) Alliance building: Strategic partnerships with other universities will promote development and dissemination of best practices in STEM education; increase recruitment of URM students from community colleges, and minority-serving and rural school districts to baccalaureate degree programs; and increase the resources and funding available to URM students. 2) Excellence: TV-LSAMP students are given skills and tools necessary to excel as both scholars and leaders and will engage in research, graduate school preparation, internships and other experiential opportunities to prepare them for roles as STEM professionals. 3) Continuous Success: TV-LSAMP builds communities of learners that foster scholarship, leadership, service and success  beyond the Alliance. Alliance program evaluation findings assessing the effectiveness of TV-LSAMP's strategies will be shared with the broader education community to build the knowledge base and implementation of best practices regarding recruiting and retention of URM in STEM disciplines.
